results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, Gaumont and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: From Daphne Du Maurier’s short story, Hitchcock has created a bizarre and violent allegory for the apocalypse, starring Tippi Hedren and Rod Taylor as young lovers who are attached by ferocious birds.

constellations_other.name: Easter Eggs on screen
constellations_other.description: People have been slipping secrets into films, games and television for as long as they have existed.

results.description: From Daphne Du Maurier’s short story, Hitchcock has created a bizarre and violent allegory for the apocalypse. A peaceful Californian coastal town is set upon by birds of all kinds who start attacking humans with increasing ferocity. Tippi Hedren and Rod Taylor star in the film as a pair of young lovers, but the real stars are the realistic special effects, the chilling sounds and music of maestro Bernard Herrmann, and Hitchcock’s gleefully sadistic flair with the film medium. Cast also includes Suzanne Pleshette and Jessica Tandy. Cinematography by Robert Burks.

results.title: Topaz [DVD]
results.brief_description: A French operative named Devereaux (Frederick Stafford) is hired by a CIA agent to travel to Cuba and investigate rumours of Russian missiles and a NATO spy group known as ‘Topaz’. They suspect there’s a traitor in the entourage of President De Gaulle. It seems that Devereaux is onto something when the investigation leads to worried governments, murder, betrayal and suicide. As he heads home to expose a double agent, his life is endangered by forces who want to keep the truth hidden. Cast includes: John Forsythe, Philippe Noiret and Dany Robin, John Vernon and Karin Dor. Screenplay by Samuel Taylor based on the novel by Leon Uris. Music composed and conducted by Maurice Jarre.

results.title: Frenzy [DVD]
results.brief_description: Hitchcock’s penultimate film and his first made in England for 20 years, ‘Frenzy’ was concerned with many of the same preoccupations that dominated his earlier work including those around the motifs of the doppelganger, the wrong man and violent sexual deviance. Post-Carnaby London is terrorised by a rapist-murderer known as the ‘Necktie Killer’. An innocent ex-R.A.F. pilot, down on his luck, is accused of the murders and condemned to life imprisonment but a police inspector continues to have doubts about his guilt. Mixing black-humour and slapstick with disturbing sexual violence, the film received the critical praise denied his three previous films but was not a commercial success. Cast includes Jon Finch, Alec McCowen, Barry Foster and Barbara Leigh-Hunt. Screenplay by Anthony Schaffer, based on Arthur Le Bern’s novel ‘ Goodbye Piccadilly, Hello Leicester Square’. Photographed by Gil Taylor. Edited by John Jympson. Music by Ron Goodwin.

results.title: Very bad things
results.creator_credit: Peter Berg, Cindy Cowan, Diane Nabatoff, Michael Schiffer, Ballpark Productions, Initial Entertainment Group (US) and Interscope Communication
results.brief_description: Very bad things is a very grim tale of morality and the bond between killers. Kyle Fisher is about to marry Laura, a neurotic, insecure woman, whose wedding plans are being administered by her in a caustic, shrill manner. Kyle’s four best friends - Adam, Michael, Charles and Robert - decide to take him to Vegas for the bucks turn, complete with drugs, booze and strippers. On the night in question one man accidentally kills a prostitute. Encouraged by Robert (Christian Slater) the group decide to bury the body in the desert. Before they can do this however a security guard discovers their crime and is promptly dispatched of also. With two bodies to dispose of the men are drawn into a gruesome pact that will assuredly be their undoing. Upon their return home the friends exchange increasingly bitter and acrimonious accusations as they attempt to deal with their misdeeds. Cameron Diaz plays Laura - the bride who will stop at nothing to have her wedding day perfect, disguising the moral degradation of those around her. Peter Berg makes his directorial debut with this very dark comedy that evokes the spirit of Tarantino, the Coen bothers and Danny Boyle. Also stars: Jeanne Tripplehorn, Daniel Stern and Jon Favreau.

results.title: The Tailor of Panama
results.brief_description: Set in 1999 Panama at the time of the handover of the canal to America, Geoffrey Rush plays Harry Pendel, an ex-con turned tailor to the towns elite. Harry meets Andrew Osnals (Pierce Brosnan), a British spy who convinces Harry to become his eyes and ears in regards to information on the political goings on in the area. What Andrew does not realise is that Harry is a master storyteller and not all that he claims to be, providing questionable information that is going to have dire consequences to all those involved in Harry’s web of deceit.

results.title: Christine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: John Carpenter, Richard Kobritz, Columbia Pictures and Polar Film
results.brief_description: Christine, a fire-engine red, 1958 Plymouth Fury that is possessed by the malevolent spirit of its long-dead owner is the woman of the title. She is jealous of anyone who tries to steal her owners’ attention. She was born in Detroit on an automobile assembly line but she is no ordinary automobile. Deep within her chassis lurks the devil incarnate and she is filled with a chilling, insatiable vengeance that will destroy anyone in her path. She seduces 17-year-old Arnie Cunningham who becomes consumed with passion for her sleek, rounded chrome-laden body. She demands his absolute and unquestioned devotion and when outsiders seek to interfere, they become victims of Christine’s uncontrollable wrath. Cast includes Keith Gordon, John Stockwell, Alexandra Paul, Robert Prosky and Harry Dean Stanton. Screenplay by Bill Phillips, based on the novel by Stephen King.

results.title: Dr. T & the women = Dr T and the women [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, James McLindon and Sandcastle 5
results.brief_description: ‘Dr.T & the women’ brings together an ensemble cast including Richard Gere, Helen Hunt, Farrah Fawcett and Kate Hudson. Gere plays Dr.T, a Dallas gynaecologist with a bevy of beautiful women who worship him. With his daughter’s wedding imminent, his wife’s lack of mental stability, his alcoholic sisters and her 3 children, it’s no wonder he finds solace in the arms of Bree, new pro teacher at the golf club.

results.title: Girlfight
results.creator_credit: Karyn Kusama, Maggie Renzi, Martha Griffin, Sarah Green and Independent Film Channel
results.brief_description: Diana Guzman (Michelle Rodriguez) is a high school student at a Bronx school who is always getting into trouble. She’s not enough of a traditional girl for the kids at school and she does not get along with her father who she blames for her mother’s death. Diana’s brother is training to be a boxer and Diana starts to secretly steal money from her dad in order to learn to box herself. When she realises that she has real talent in the ring, she finds a purpose and a drive in life that she never thought she had. Karyn Kusama’s debut feature film is an exceptionally resonant and effective piece of filmmaking that superbly conveys the intimate story of a young Hispanic girl’s life. Eschewing conventional plotting by enfusing all the characters with ambiguity and complexity, “Girlfight” is a truly inspiring neo-feminist coming of age story. Both the female and male characters in the film are treated sensitively, and with a refreshing disavowal of the usual gender and racial stereotypes accorded to the representation of Hispanic Americans. The film won both the Directing and Grand Jury Prize at the 2000 Sundance Festival and there has also been international acclaim for Rodriguez whose feature film debut it is. The film also features a cameo appearance by independent filmmaker John Sayles who helped finance the film. The featurette accompanying this DVD features in-depth interviews with Kusama and with the actors in the film.

results.title: Krull
results.creator_credit: Peter Yates, Ron Silverman and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in the fantastic kingdom of Krull, our plot starts with the revelation that the kingdom is under threat from the indescribable Beast and his army of Slayers. Eager to forge an alliance, Prince Colwyn (Ken Marshall) and Princess Lyssa (Lysette Anthony) plan to marry. During the wedding ceremony however, slayers attack, killing Colwyn’s father and kidnapping Lyssa and taking her to the black fortress. Waking to discover he has lost his father and his bride, Colwyn is advised by the wise Ynyr that he must retrieve the Glaive - a starfish shaped, jewel encrusted symbol with retractable blades - which, given the right bearer, is the only thing that can defeat the Beast. Colwyn recruits a motley crew of renegades (including reputable actors such as Liam Neeson and Bernard Bresslaw), to accompany him on his quest. A curious blend of science fiction and medieval iconography, “Krull” has all the resident tenets of a fantasy; damsel in distress, love that can cure all evil, an almighty quest and final showdown between hero and villain. Whilst receiving a G classification, there are a few ghoulish moments which belie the general rating. Made on a budget in excess of 45 million, the film received cult rather than commercial success. Written by Stanford Sherman.

results.title: The Garden of the Finzi-Continis = Il Giardino dei Finzi-Contini
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Sica, Arthur Cohn, Gianni Hecht Lucari, CCC Filmkunst and Documento Films
results.brief_description: Made towards the end of his life, de Sica’s “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” is one of the Italian director’s finest achievements. In this movie de Sica turns his gaze away from the urban working class lives that dominated his neo-realist cinema, and instead focuses on the lives of an aristocratic Jewish family leading up to the tragedy of World War II. Based on Giorgio Bassini’s acclaimed novel of the same name, the film details the experiences of love, family and politics as seen through the eyes of the adults and the adolescents in the Finzi-Contini family. The children attempt to make their mansion a refuge against fascism, a perpetual romantic space to re-live their childhood games and preoccupations. The adults, in turn, hope that by accommodating to the increasingly humiliating “race-laws” they will buy time and live to see the restoration of the old social order. But as Italy joins Germany in war, all their attempts prove futile against the savage anti-Semitism of fascism. In the film’s devastating concluding passage, the tragedy of European twentieth-century history is conveyed in the stark faces of the family, stripped of their luxuries and belongings; stripped of their illusions and their hope. The film is a loving remembrance of a specifically Italian Jewish history and culture: de Sica’s ability to immerse us in the textures and colours of a vanquished past is one of this film’s greatest achievements. It’s dignified simplicity in presenting the horror of the Holocaust makes it one of the most eloquent of anti-war films. (Awards: Winner of the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. Winner of the Golden Bear at the Venice Film Festival. With Dominique Sanda, Helmut Berger) In Italian with English subtitles.

The children attempt to make their mansion a refuge against fascism, a perpetual romantic space to re-live their childhood games and preoccupations. The adults, in turn, hope that by accommodating to the increasingly humiliating “race-laws” they will buy time and live to see the restoration of the old social order. But as Italy joins Germany in war, all their attempts prove futile against the savage anti-Semitism of fascism. In the film’s devastating concluding passage, the tragedy of European twentieth-century history is conveyed in the stark faces of the family, stripped of their luxuries and belongings; stripped of their illusions and their hope. The film is a loving remembrance of a specifically Italian Jewish history and culture: de Sica’s ability to immerse us in the textures and colours of a vanquished past is one of this film’s greatest achievements. It’s dignified simplicity in presenting the horror of the Holocaust makes it one of the most eloquent of anti-war films. (Awards: Winner of the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. Winner of the Golden Bear at the Venice Film Festival. With Dominique Sanda, Helmut Berger) In Italian with English subtitles.
